what: An R-Package for Clinical Significance Analyses
title: An R-Package for Clinical Significance Analyses
text: goal package provide necessary tools analyses clinical significance clinical intervention studies. contrast statistical significance, assesses probable treatment effect, clinical significance can used determine treatment effect practical use meaningful patients.

title: An R-Package for Clinical Significance Analyses
text: can install clinicalsignificance CRAN development version GitHub:
code: install.packages("clinicalsignificance")  # Or you install the development version from GitHub: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("pedscience/clinicalsignificance")

title: An R-Package for Clinical Significance Analyses
text: Given tidy dataset, employed instrument’s reliability minimal important difference instrument, clinical significance analysis can calculated following function call. can receive detailed summary analysis plot results
code: library(clinicalsignificance)  results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_anchor(     id = id,     time = time,     outcome = bdi,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     mid_improvement = 7   )  results #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Individual anchor-based approach with a 7 point decrease in instrument scores #> indicating a clinical significant improvement. #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 25 |    0.62 #> Unchanged    | 11 |    0.28 #> Deteriorated |  4 |    0.10 summary(results) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Individual anchor-based analysis of clinical significance with a 7 point #> decrease in instrument scores (bdi) indicating a clinical significant #> improvement. #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which 40 (93%) could be #> included in the analysis. #>  #> ── Individual Level Results #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 25 |    0.62 #> Unchanged    | 11 |    0.28 #> Deteriorated |  4 |    0.10 plot(results)

title: Antidepressant Data — antidepressants
text: fictional clinical trial, effectiveness new antidepressant examined depressed patients randomized one four groups: wait list control group receive medication inactive placebo group, .e., group received placebo (inert substance without proposed clinical effect) pill active placebo group, .e., group received placebo evokes side effects like mild nausea dry mouth antidepressant group, target medication trial clinical impact patients' depressive symptoms Suppose underwent outpatient treatment, depressive symptoms measured treatment Mind Mood Depression Inventory (MoM-DI) Greenberger & Padesky (2015), patient received pill, clinician patient know, type medicaction consumed. , minimal important difference improvement measured instrument agreed 8 point decrease. deterioration can assumed instrument scores increased 5 points. functional population (.e., non-depressed individuals) can expected mean score M = 8 points standard deviation SD = 7.

code: # Augmented data can be extracted for every individual approach anchor_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_anchor(     id,     time,     bdi,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     mid_improvement = 9   )   distribution_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_distribution(     id,     time,     bdi,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     reliability = 0.80   )   distribution_results_hlm <- claus_2020 |>   cs_distribution(     id,     time,     bdi,     rci_method = "HLM"   )   statistical_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_statistical(     id,     time,     bdi,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     m_functional = 8,     sd_functional = 8   )   combined_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_combined(     id,     time,     bdi,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     m_functional = 8,     sd_functional = 8,     reliability = 0.80   )   cs_get_augmented_data(anchor_results) #> # text: data tidy data frame id Participant ID time Time variable outcome Outcome variable group Grouping variable (optional) pre Pre measurement (needed time variable contains two measurements) post Post measurement (needed time variable contains two measurements) mid_improvement Numeric, change indicates clinically significant improvement mid_deterioration Numeric, change indicates clinically significant deterioration (optional). mid_deterioration provided, assumed equal mid_improvement better_is direction means better outcome used instrument? Available "lower" (lower outcome scores desirable, default) "higher" (higher outcome scores desirable) target String, whether individual group analysis calculated. Available "individual" (default) every individual participant evaluated "group" group wise effect evaluated effect String, target = "group", specify effect calculated. Available "within" (default), yields mean pre-post intervention difference associated confidence intervals "", estimates group wise mean difference confidence intervals two groups specified group argument specified measurement supplied post- argument reference group may supplied reference_group bayesian Logical, relevant target = "group". Indicates Bayesian estimate (.e., median) group differences credible interval calculated (set TRUE, default) frequentist mean difference confidence interval (set FALSE) prior_scale String numeric, can adjusted change Bayesian prior distribution. title: Anchor-Based Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_anchor
text: individual-level analyses, analysis straight forward. MID can specified improvement well deterioration (must necessarily identical) function basically counts many patients fall within MID range , improvement deterioration, many patients exceed limits range either direction. patient may categorized : Improved, patient demonstrated change equal greater MID improvement Unchanged, patient demonstrated change less MIDs Deteriorated, patient demonstrated change equal greater MID deterioration group-level analyses, whole sample either treated single group split grouping presented data. within group analyses, function calculates median change pre post intervention associated credible interval (CI). Based median change limits CI, group change can categorized 5 distinctive categories: Statistically significant, CI contains 0 Statistically significant clinically relevant, CI contain 0, median CI limits beneath MID threshold significantly less threshold, MID threshold falls within CI median still threshold Probably clinically significant effect, median crossed MID threshold threshold still inside CI Large clinically significant effect, median crossed MID threshold CI contain threshold group comparison desired, reference group can defined reference_group argument subsequent groups compared. usually inactive comparator placebo wait-list control group. difference pairwise compared groups categorized just within group difference , categories apply. approach can changed classical frequentist framework point estimate represents mean difference CI confidence interval. extensive overview differences Bayesian frequentist CI, refer Hespanhol et al. (2019).

what: Combined Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_combined
title: Combined Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_combined
text: cs_combined() can used determine clinical significance intervention studies employing combination distribution-based statistical approach. , assumed functional (non-clinical population) patient (clinical population) scores form two distinct distributions continuum. cs_combined() calculates cutoff point two populations well reliable change index (RCI) based provided instrument reliability estimate counts, many patients showed reliable change (likely due measurement error) switched clinical functional population intervention. Several methods calculating cutoff RCI available.

code: cs_combined(   data,   id,   time,   outcome,   group = NULL,   pre = NULL,   post = NULL,   reliability = NULL,   reliability_post = NULL,   m_functional = NULL,   sd_functional = NULL,   better_is = c("lower", "higher"),   rci_method = c("JT", "GLN", "HLL", "EN", "NK", "HA", "HLM"),   cutoff_type = c("a", "b", "c"),   significance_level = 0.05 )

Available "lower" (lower outcome scores desirable, default) "higher" (higher outcome scores desirable) rci_method Clinical significance method. Available "JT" (Jacobson & Truax, 1991, default) "GLN" (Gulliksen, Lord, Novick; Hsu, 1989, Hsu, 1995) "HLL" (Hsu, Linn & Nord; Hsu, 1989) "EN" (Edwards & Nunnally; Speer, 1992) "NK" (Nunnally & Kotsch, 1983), requires reliability estimate post measurement. supplied, reliability reliability_post assumed equal "HA" (Hageman & Arrindell, 1999) "HLM" (Hierarchical Linear Modeling; Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002), requires least three measurements per patient cutoff_type Cutoff type. "positive" outcomes, higher scores beneficial, mean clinical population plus 2 \(\cdot\) SD clinical population b mean functional population minus 2 \(\cdot\) SD clinical population. summary statistics clinical population estimated provided data pre measurement. c defined midpoint populations based respective mean SD. order calculate b c, descriptive statistics functional population must provided. provided data, region change calculated individual change may likely due inherent measurement used instrument. concept also known minimally detectable change (MDC).

title: Distribution-Based Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_distribution
text: data tidy data frame id Participant ID time Time variable outcome Outcome variable group Grouping variable (optional) pre Pre measurement (needed time variable contains two measurements) post Post measurement (needed time variable contains two measurements) reliability instrument's reliability estimate. selected NK method, specified reliability instrument's pre measurement reliability. needed HLM method. reliability_post instrument's reliability post measurement (needed NK method) better_is direction means better outcome used instrument? Available "lower" (lower outcome scores desirable, default) "higher" (higher outcome scores desirable) rci_method Clinical significance method. Available "JT" (Jacobson & Truax, 1991, default) "GLN" (Gulliksen, Lord, Novick; Hsu, 1989, Hsu, 1995) "HLL" (Hsu, Linn & Nord; Hsu, 1989) "EN" (Edwards & Nunnally; Speer, 1992) "NK" (Nunnally & Kotsch, 1983), requires reliability estimate post measurement. supplied, reliability reliability_post assumed equal "HA" (Hageman & Arrindell, 1999) "HLM" (Hierarchical Linear Modeling; Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002), requires least three measurements per patient significance_level Significance level alpha, defaults 0.05. choose "HA" method, value corresponds maximum risk misclassification

title: Distribution-Based Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_distribution
code: antidepressants |>   cs_distribution(patient, measurement, mom_di, reliability = 0.80) #> ℹ Your "Before" was set as pre measurement and and your "After" as post. #> • If that is not correct, please specify the pre measurement with the argument #>   "pre". #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Distribution-based approach using the JT method. #>  #> Category     |   n | Percent #> ---------------------------- #> Improved     | 274 |    0.49 #> Unchanged    | 237 |    0.43 #> Deteriorated |  44 |    0.08   # Turn off the warning by providing the pre measurement time cs_results <- antidepressants |>   cs_distribution(     patient,     measurement,     mom_di,     pre = "Before",     reliability = 0.80   )  summary(cs_results) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Distribution-based analysis of clinical significance using the JT method for #> calculating the RCI. #>  #> There were 555 participants in the whole dataset of which 555 (100%) could be #> included in the analysis. #>  #> The outcome was mom_di and the reliability was set to 0.8. #>  #>  #> ── Individual Level Results  #> Category     |   n | Percent #> ---------------------------- #> Improved     | 274 |    0.49 #> Unchanged    | 237 |    0.43 #> Deteriorated |  44 |    0.08 plot(cs_results)    # If you use data with more than two measurements, you always have to define a # pre and post measurement cs_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_distribution(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     reliability = 0.80   )  cs_results #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Distribution-based approach using the JT method. #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 29 |    0.72 #> Unchanged    | 10 |    0.25 #> Deteriorated |  1 |    0.03 summary(cs_results) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Distribution-based analysis of clinical significance using the JT method for #> calculating the RCI. #>  #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which 40 (93%) could be #> included in the analysis. #>  #> The outcome was hamd and the reliability was set to 0.8. #>  #>  #> ── Individual Level Results  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 29 |    0.72 #> Unchanged    | 10 |    0.25 #> Deteriorated |  1 |    0.03 plot(cs_results)    # Set the rci_method argument to change the RCI method cs_results_ha <- claus_2020 |>   cs_distribution(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     reliability = 0.80,     rci_method = "HA"   )  cs_results_ha #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Distribution-based approach using the HA method. #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 32 |    0.80 #> Unchanged    |  7 |    0.17 #> Deteriorated |  1 |    0.03 summary(cs_results_ha) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Distribution-based analysis of clinical significance using the HA method for #> calculating the RCI. #>  #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which 40 (93%) could be #> included in the analysis. #>  #> The outcome was hamd and the reliability was set to 0.8. #>  #>  #> ── Individual Level Results  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 32 |    0.80 #> Unchanged    |  7 |    0.17 #> Deteriorated |  1 |    0.03 plot(cs_results_ha)    # Group the analysis by providing a grouping variable cs_results_grouped <- claus_2020 |>   cs_distribution(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     group = treatment,     reliability = 0.80   )  cs_results_grouped #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Distribution-based approach using the JT method. #>  #> Group |     Category |  n | Percent #> ----------------------------------- #> TAU   |     Improved |  9 |    0.23 #> TAU   |    Unchanged |  9 |    0.23 #> TAU   | Deteriorated |  1 |    0.03 #> PA    |     Improved | 20 |    0.50 #> PA    |    Unchanged |  1 |    0.03 #> PA    | Deteriorated |  0 |    0.00 summary(cs_results_grouped) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Distribution-based analysis of clinical significance using the JT method for #> calculating the RCI. #>  #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which 40 (93%) could be #> included in the analysis. #>  #> The outcome was hamd and the reliability was set to 0.8. #>  #>  #> ── Individual Level Results  #> Group |     Category |  n | Percent #> ----------------------------------- #> TAU   |     Improved |  9 |    0.23 #> TAU   |    Unchanged |  9 |    0.23 #> TAU   | Deteriorated |  1 |    0.03 #> PA    |     Improved | 20 |    0.50 #> PA    |    Unchanged |  1 |    0.03 #> PA    | Deteriorated |  0 |    0.00 plot(cs_results_grouped)    # Use more than two measurements cs_results_hlm <- claus_2020 |>   cs_distribution(     id,     time,     hamd,     rci_method = "HLM"   )  cs_results_hlm #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Distribution-based approach using the HLM method. #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 11 |    0.28 #> Unchanged    | 20 |    0.50 #> Deteriorated |  9 |    0.23 summary(cs_results_hlm) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Distribution-based analysis of clinical significance using the HLM method for #> calculating the RCI. #>  #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which 40 (93%) could be #> included in the analysis. #>  #> The outcome was hamd. #>  #>  #> ── Individual Level Results  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 11 |    0.28 #> Unchanged    | 20 |    0.50 #> Deteriorated |  9 |    0.23 plot(cs_results_hlm)

Also, column containing different measurements outcome must supplied. participant-measurement combination must unique, instance, data must contain two "" measurements patient. Additionally, measurement column contains two values, first value based alphabetical, numerical factor ordering used pre measurement. instance, column contains measurements identifiers "pre" "post" strings, "post" sorted "pre" thus used "pre" measurement. function throw warning generally may want explicitly define "pre" "post" measurement arguments pre post. case two measurement identifiers, define pre post manually since function know pre post intervention measurements . data grouped, can specify group referencing grouping variable (see examples ). analysis run every group compare group differences.

title: Percentage-Change Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_percentage
code: cs_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_percentage(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     pct_improvement = 0.3   )  cs_results #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Percentage-change approach with a 30% decrease in instrument scores indicating #> a clinical significant improvement. #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 25 |    0.62 #> Unchanged    | 15 |    0.38 #> Deteriorated |  0 |    0.00 summary(cs_results) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Percentage-change analysis of clinical significance with a 30% decrease in #> instrument scores indicating a clinical significant improvement. #>  #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which 40 (93%) could be #> included in the analysis. #>  #>  #> ── Individual Level Results  #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 25 |    0.62 #> Unchanged    | 15 |    0.38 #> Deteriorated |  0 |    0.00 plot(cs_results)    # You can set different thresholds for improvement and deterioration cs_results_2 <- claus_2020 |>   cs_percentage(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     pct_improvement = 0.3,     pct_deterioration = 0.2   )  cs_results_2 #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Percentage-change approach with a 30% decrease in instrument scores indicating #> a clinical significant improvement and a 20% increase in instrument scores #> indicating a clinical significant deterioration. #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 25 |    0.62 #> Unchanged    | 14 |    0.35 #> Deteriorated |  1 |    0.03 summary(cs_results_2) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Percentage-change analysis of clinical significance with a 30% decrease in #> instrument scores indicating a clinical significant improvement and a 20% #> increase in instrument scores indicating a clinical significant deterioration. #>  #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which 40 (93%) could be #> included in the analysis. #>  #>  #> ── Individual Level Results  #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 25 |    0.62 #> Unchanged    | 14 |    0.35 #> Deteriorated |  1 |    0.03 plot(cs_results_2)    # You can group the analysis by providing a group column from the data cs_results_grouped <- claus_2020 |>   cs_percentage(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     pct_improvement = 0.3,     group = treatment   )  cs_results_grouped #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Percentage-change approach with a 30% decrease in instrument scores indicating #> a clinical significant improvement. #>  #> Group |     Category |  n | Percent #> ----------------------------------- #> TAU   |     Improved |  6 |    0.15 #> TAU   |    Unchanged | 13 |    0.33 #> TAU   | Deteriorated |  0 |    0.00 #> PA    |     Improved | 19 |    0.47 #> PA    |    Unchanged |  2 |    0.05 #> PA    | Deteriorated |  0 |    0.00 summary(cs_results_grouped) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Percentage-change analysis of clinical significance with a 30% decrease in #> instrument scores indicating a clinical significant improvement. #>  #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which 40 (93%) could be #> included in the analysis. #>  #>  #> ── Individual Level Results  #>  #> Group |     Category |  n | Percent #> ----------------------------------- #> TAU   |     Improved |  6 |    0.15 #> TAU   |    Unchanged | 13 |    0.33 #> TAU   | Deteriorated |  0 |    0.00 #> PA    |     Improved | 19 |    0.47 #> PA    |    Unchanged |  2 |    0.05 #> PA    | Deteriorated |  0 |    0.00 plot(cs_results_grouped)    # The analyses can be performed for positive outcomes as well, i.e., outcomes # for which a higher value is beneficial cs_results_who <- claus_2020 |>   cs_percentage(     id,     time,     who,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     pct_improvement = 0.3,     better_is = "higher"   )  cs_results_who #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Percentage-change approach with a 30% increase in instrument scores indicating #> a clinical significant improvement. #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 28 |    0.70 #> Unchanged    |  9 |    0.23 #> Deteriorated |  3 |    0.07 summary(cs_results_who) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Percentage-change analysis of clinical significance with a 30% increase in #> instrument scores indicating a clinical significant improvement. #>  #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which 40 (93%) could be #> included in the analysis. #>  #>  #> ── Individual Level Results  #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 28 |    0.70 #> Unchanged    |  9 |    0.23 #> Deteriorated |  3 |    0.07 plot(cs_results_who)  plot(cs_results_who, show = category)

what: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
text: cs_statistical() can used determine clinical significance intervention studies employing statistical approach. , assumed functional (non-clinical population) patient (clinical population) scores form two distinct distributions continuum. cs_statistical() calculates cutoff point two populations counts, many patients changed clinical functional population intervention. Several methods calculating cutoff available.

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
code: cs_statistical(   data,   id,   time,   outcome,   group = NULL,   pre = NULL,   post = NULL,   m_functional = NULL,   sd_functional = NULL,   reliability = NULL,   better_is = c("lower", "higher"),   cutoff_method = c("JT", "HA"),   cutoff_type = c("a", "b", "c"),   significance_level = 0.05 )

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
text: data tidy data frame id Participant ID time Time variable outcome Outcome variable group Grouping variable (optional) pre Pre measurement (needed time variable contains two measurements) post Post measurement (needed time variable contains two measurements) m_functional Numeric, mean functional population. sd_functional Numeric, standard deviation functional population reliability instrument's reliability estimate. selected NK method, specified reliability instrument's pre measurement reliability. needed HLM method. better_is direction means better outcome used instrument? Available "lower" (lower outcome scores desirable, default) "higher" (higher outcome scores desirable) cutoff_method Cutoff method, Available "JT" (Jacobson & Truax, 1991, default) "HA" (Hageman & Arrindell, 1999) cutoff_type Cutoff type. Available "", "b", "c". Defaults "" "c" usually recommended. "b" "c", summary data functional population must given arguments m_functional sd_functional. significance_level Significance level alpha, defaults 0.05. choose "HA" method, value corresponds maximum risk misclassification

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
text: S3 object class cs_analysis cs_statistical

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
text: three available cutoff types, namely , b, c can used "draw line" separate functional clinical population continuum. cutoff defined mean clinical population minus two times standard deviation (SD) clinical population. b defined mean functional population plus also two times SD clinical population. true "negative" outcomes, lower instrument score desirable. "positive" outcomes, higher scores beneficial, mean clinical population plus 2 \(\cdot\) SD clinical population b mean functional population minus 2 \(\cdot\) SD clinical population. summary statistics clinical population estimated provided data pre measurement. c defined midpoint populations based respective mean SD. order calculate b c, descriptive statistics functional population must provided.

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
text: Individual patients can categorized one following groups: Improved, .e., one changed clinical functional population Unchanged, .e., one can seen member population pre post intervention Deteriorated, .e., one changed functional clinical population intervention

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
text: Jacobson, N. S., & Truax, P. (1991). Clinical significance: statistical approach defining meaningful change psychotherapy research. Journal Consulting Clinical Psychology, 59(1), 12–19. https://doi.org/10.1037//0022-006X.59.1.12 Hageman, W. J., & Arrindell, W. . (1999). Establishing clinically significant change: increment precision distinction individual group level analysis. Behaviour Research Therapy, 37(12), 1169–1193. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0005-7967(99)00032-7

title: Statistical Analysis of Clinical Significance — cs_statistical
code: # By default, cutoff type "a" is used cs_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_statistical(id, time, hamd, pre = 1, post = 4)  cs_results #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Statistical approach using the JT method. #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 26 |    0.65 #> Unchanged    | 13 |    0.33 #> Deteriorated |  1 |    0.03 summary(cs_results) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Statistical approach of clinical significance using the JT method for #> calculating the population cutoff. #>  #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which 40 (93%) could be #> included in the analysis. #>  #> The cutoff type was a with a value of 18.17 based on the following sumamry #> statistics: #>  #>  #> ── Population Characteristics  #> M Clinical | SD Clinical | M Functional | SD Functional #> ------------------------------------------------------- #> 24.85      |        3.34 |          --- |           --- #>  #>  #> ── Individual Level Results  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 26 |    0.65 #> Unchanged    | 13 |    0.33 #> Deteriorated |  1 |    0.03 plot(cs_results)    # You can choose a different cutoff type but need to provide additional # population summary statistics for the functional population cs_results_c <- claus_2020 |>   cs_statistical(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     m_functional = 8,     sd_functional = 8,     cutoff_type = "c"   )  cs_results_c #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Statistical approach using the JT method. #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 26 |    0.65 #> Unchanged    | 13 |    0.33 #> Deteriorated |  1 |    0.03 summary(cs_results_c) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Statistical approach of clinical significance using the JT method for #> calculating the population cutoff. #>  #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which 40 (93%) could be #> included in the analysis. #>  #> The cutoff type was c with a value of 19.89 based on the following sumamry #> statistics: #>  #>  #> ── Population Characteristics  #> M Clinical | SD Clinical | M Functional | SD Functional #> ------------------------------------------------------- #> 24.85      |        3.34 |            8 |             8 #>  #>  #> ── Individual Level Results  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 26 |    0.65 #> Unchanged    | 13 |    0.33 #> Deteriorated |  1 |    0.03 plot(cs_results_c)    # You can use a different method to calculate the cutoff cs_results_ha <- claus_2020 |>   cs_statistical(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     m_functional = 8,     sd_functional = 8,     reliability = 0.80,     cutoff_type = "c",     cutoff_method = "HA"   )  cs_results_ha #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Statistical approach using the HA method. #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 23 |    0.57 #> Unchanged    | 17 |    0.42 #> Deteriorated |  0 |    0.00 summary(cs_results_ha) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Statistical approach of clinical significance using the HA method for #> calculating the population cutoff. #>  #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which 40 (93%) could be #> included in the analysis. #>  #> The cutoff type was c_true with a value of 20.21 based on the following sumamry #> statistics: #>  #>  #> ── Population Characteristics  #> M Clinical | SD Clinical | M Functional | SD Functional #> ------------------------------------------------------- #> 24.85      |        3.34 |            8 |             8 #>  #>  #> ── Individual Level Results  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Improved     | 23 |    0.57 #> Unchanged    | 17 |    0.42 #> Deteriorated |  0 |    0.00 plot(cs_results_ha)    # And you can group the analysis by providing a grouping variable from the data cs_results_grouped <- claus_2020 |>   cs_statistical(     id,     time,     hamd,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     m_functional = 8,     sd_functional = 8,     cutoff_type = "c",     group = treatment   )  cs_results_grouped #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Statistical approach using the JT method. #>  #> Group |     Category |  n | Percent #> ----------------------------------- #> TAU   |     Improved |  7 |    0.17 #> TAU   |    Unchanged | 11 |    0.28 #> TAU   | Deteriorated |  1 |    0.03 #> PA    |     Improved | 19 |    0.47 #> PA    |    Unchanged |  2 |    0.05 #> PA    | Deteriorated |  0 |    0.00 summary(cs_results_grouped) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Statistical approach of clinical significance using the JT method for #> calculating the population cutoff. #>  #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which 40 (93%) could be #> included in the analysis. #>  #> The cutoff type was c with a value of 19.89 based on the following sumamry #> statistics: #>  #>  #> ── Population Characteristics  #> M Clinical | SD Clinical | M Functional | SD Functional #> ------------------------------------------------------- #> 24.85      |        3.34 |            8 |             8 #>  #>  #> ── Individual Level Results  #> Group |     Category |  n | Percent #> ----------------------------------- #> TAU   |     Improved |  7 |    0.17 #> TAU   |    Unchanged | 11 |    0.28 #> TAU   | Deteriorated |  1 |    0.03 #> PA    |     Improved | 19 |    0.47 #> PA    |    Unchanged |  2 |    0.05 #> PA    | Deteriorated |  0 |    0.00 plot(cs_results_grouped)

code: cs_results <- antidepressants |>   cs_anchor(     patient,     measurement,     pre = "Before",     mom_di,     mid_improvement = 8   )   # Plot the results "as is" plot(cs_results)    # Change the axis labels plot(cs_results, x_lab = "Before Intervention", y_lab = "After Intervention")    # Show the individual categories plot(cs_results, show = category)    # Show a specific category plot(cs_results, show = improved)    # Show groups as specified in the data cs_results_grouped <- antidepressants |>   cs_anchor(     patient,     measurement,     pre = "Before",     mom_di,     mid_improvement = 8,     group = condition   )  plot(cs_results_grouped)    # To avoid overplotting, generic ggplot2 code can be used to facet the plot library(ggplot2) plot(cs_results_grouped) +   facet_wrap(~ group)    # Adjust the transparency of individual data points plot(cs_results, point_alpha = 0.3)    # Adjust the fill and transparency of the "unchanged" (PCC) region plot(cs_results, mid_fill = "firebrick", mid_alpha = 0.2)    # Control the overplotting plot(cs_results, overplotting = 0.1)    # Or adjust the axis limits by hand plot(cs_results, lower_limit = 0, upper_limit = 80)

text: function creates generic clinical significance plot plotting patients' pre intervention value x-axis post intervention score y-axis.

title: Plot an Object of Class cs_percentage — plot.cs_percentage
code: # S3 method for cs_percentage plot(   x,   x_lab = "Pre",   y_lab = "Post",   color_lab = "Group",   lower_limit,   upper_limit,   show,   point_alpha = 1,   pct_fill = "grey10",   pct_alpha = 0.1,   overplotting = 0.02,   ... )

title: Plot an Object of Class cs_percentage — plot.cs_percentage
text: x object class cs_distribution x_lab String, x axis label. Default "Pre". y_lab String, x axis label. Default "Post". color_lab String, color label (colors displayed). Default "Group" lower_limit Numeric, lower plotting limit. Defaults 2% smaller minimum instrument score upper_limit Numeric, upper plotting limit. Defaults 2% larger maximum instrument score show Unquoted category name. several options color different features. Available improved (shows improved participants) unchanged (shows unchanged participants) deteriorated (shows deteriorated participants) point_alpha Numeric, transparency adjustment points. value 0 1 1 corresponds transparent 0 fully transparent. pct_fill String, color (name HEX code) percentage range fill pct_alpha Numeric, controls transparency percentage fill. can value 0 1, defaults 0.1 overplotting Numeric, control amount overplotting. Defaults 0.02 (.e., 2% range lower upper limit). ... Additional arguments

title: Plot an Object of Class cs_percentage — plot.cs_percentage
text: ggplot2 plot

title: Plot an Object of Class cs_percentage — plot.cs_percentage
code: cs_results <- antidepressants |>   cs_percentage(     patient,     measurement,     pre = "Before",     mom_di,     pct_improvement = 0.4   )   # Plot the results "as is" plot(cs_results)    # Change the axis labels plot(cs_results, x_lab = "Before Intervention", y_lab = "After Intervention")    # Show the individual categories plot(cs_results, show = category)    # Show a specific category plot(cs_results, show = improved)    # Show groups as specified in the data cs_results_grouped <- antidepressants |>   cs_percentage(     patient,     measurement,     pre = "Before",     mom_di,     pct_improvement = 0.4,     group = condition   )  plot(cs_results_grouped)    # To avoid overplotting, generic ggplot2 code can be used to facet the plot library(ggplot2) plot(cs_results_grouped) +   facet_wrap(~ group)    # Adjust the transparency of individual data points plot(cs_results, point_alpha = 0.3)    # Adjust the fill and transparency of the "unchanged" (PCC) region plot(cs_results, pct_fill = "firebrick", pct_alpha = 0.2)    # Control the overplotting plot(cs_results, overplotting = 0.1)    # Or adjust the axis limits by hand plot(cs_results, lower_limit = 0, upper_limit = 80)

title: Plot an Object of Class cs_statistical — plot.cs_statistical
text: x object class cs_statistical x_lab String, x axis label. Default "Pre". y_lab String, x axis label. Default "Post". color_lab String, color label (colors displayed). Default "Group" include_cutoff Logical, whether include population cutoff. Default TRUE. lower_limit Numeric, lower plotting limit. Defaults 2% smaller minimum instrument score upper_limit Numeric, upper plotting limit. Defaults 2% larger maximum instrument score show Unquoted category name. several options color different features. Available category (shows categories ) clinical_pre (shows participants clinical scores pre intervention) functional_post (shows participants functional scores post intervention) unchanged (shows unchanged participants) point_alpha Numeric, transparency adjustment points. value 0 1 1 corresponds transparent 0 fully transparent. overplotting Numeric, control amount overplotting. Defaults 0.02 (.e., 2% range lower upper limit). ... Additional arguments

title: Plot an Object of Class cs_statistical — plot.cs_statistical
code: cs_results <- antidepressants |>   cs_statistical(     patient,     measurement,     pre = "Before",     mom_di,     m_functional = 15,     sd_functional = 8,     cutoff_type = "c"   )   # Plot the results "as is" plot(cs_results)    # Change the axis labels plot(cs_results, x_lab = "Before Intervention", y_lab = "After Intervention")    # Show the individual categories plot(cs_results, show = category)    # Show groups as specified in the data cs_results_grouped <- antidepressants |>   cs_statistical(     patient,     measurement,     pre = "Before",     mom_di,     m_functional = 15,     sd_functional = 8,     cutoff_type = "c",     group = condition   )  plot(cs_results_grouped)    # To avoid overplotting, generic ggplot2 code can be used to facet the plot library(ggplot2) plot(cs_results_grouped) +   facet_wrap(~ group)    # Adjust the transparency of individual data points plot(cs_results, point_alpha = 0.3)    # Control the overplotting plot(cs_results, overplotting = 0.1)    # Or adjust the axis limits by hand plot(cs_results, lower_limit = 0, upper_limit = 80)

code: cs_results <- antidepressants |>   cs_anchor(     patient,     measurement,     post = "After",     mom_di,     mid_improvement = 8,     target = "group",     effect = "between",     group = condition   )  summary(cs_results) #>  #> ── Clinical Significance Results ── #>  #> Groupwise anchor-based analysis of clinical significance (between groups) with #> a 8 point decrease in instrument scores (mom_di) indicating a clinical #> significant improvement. #>  #>  #> ── Group Level Results  #>  #> Group 1   | Group 2          | Median Difference | [Lower | Upper] | CI-Level | n (1) | n (2) | Category                            #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> Wait List | Inactive Placebo | -11.70            | -13.38 | -10.06 | 0.95     | 152   | 130   | Large clinically significant effect #> Wait List | Active Placebo   | -17.71            | -19.42 | -15.92 | 0.95     | 152   | 121   | Large clinically significant effect #> Wait List | Antidepressant   | -18.45            | -20.16 | -16.76 | 0.95     | 152   | 152   | Large clinically significant effect

what: Get A Summary Table From A cs_analysis Object — cs_get_summary
title: Get A Summary Table From A cs_analysis Object — cs_get_summary
text: Retrieve summary table tidy tibble format. especially useful plot results conduct sensitivity analyses.

title: Get A Summary Table From A cs_analysis Object — cs_get_summary
code: cs_get_summary(x, ...)  # S3 method for default cs_get_summary(x, which = c("individual", "group"), ...)  # S3 method for cs_anchor_group_within cs_get_summary(x, ...)  # S3 method for cs_anchor_group_between cs_get_summary(x, ...)

title: Get A Summary Table From A cs_analysis Object — cs_get_summary
text: x object class cs_analysis ... Additional arguments passed respective method level summary table return. necessary method "HA" since two summary tables reported. Available individual, default group, group level results according Hageman & Arrindell (1999)

title: Get A Summary Table From A cs_analysis Object — cs_get_summary
text: tibble clinical significance categories

title: Get A Summary Table From A cs_analysis Object — cs_get_summary
text: Hageman, W. J., & Arrindell, W. . (1999). Establishing clinically significant change: increment precision distinction individual group level analysis. Behaviour Research Therapy, 37(12), 1169–1193. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0005-7967(99)00032-7

title: Get A Summary Table From A cs_analysis Object — cs_get_summary
code: anchor_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_anchor(     id,     time,     bdi,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     mid_improvement = 8   )  cs_get_summary(anchor_results) #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   category         n percent #>   <fct>        <int>   <dbl> #> 1 Improved        20   0.5   #> 2 Unchanged       17   0.425 #> 3 Deteriorated     3   0.075   # Get summary table for a group level analysis anchor_results_grouped <- claus_2020 |>   cs_anchor(     id,     time,     bdi,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     mid_improvement = 8,     target = "group"   )  cs_get_summary(anchor_results_grouped) #> # A tibble: 1 × 6 #>   difference lower upper    ci     n category                               #>        <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <int> <chr>                                  #> 1      -9.46 -13.0 -5.93  0.95    40 Probably clinically significant effect   # Get group-wise summary table for the Hageman & Arrindell method combined_results <- claus_2020 |>   cs_combined(     id,     time,     bdi,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     m_functional = 8,     sd_functional = 8,     reliability = 0.80,     rci_method = "HA"   )  cs_get_summary(combined_results) #> # A tibble: 5 × 3 #>   category         n percent #>   <fct>        <int>   <dbl> #> 1 Recovered        7   0.175 #> 2 Improved        18   0.45  #> 3 Unchanged       15   0.375 #> 4 Deteriorated     0   0     #> 5 Harmed           0   0     cs_get_summary(combined_results, which = "group") #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   category   percent #>   <chr>        <dbl> #> 1 Changed      0.841 #> 2 Functional   0.354

title: clinicalsignificance (development version)
text: cs_anchor() (Anchor-based approaches) cs_percentage()(Percentage-change approaches) cs_distribution()(Distribution-based approaches) cs_statistical()(Statistical approaches) cs_combined()(Combined approaches) function clinical_significance() used combined approach (distribution-based statistical). identical analysis can carried cs_combined(). function check_cutoff() deprecated. method = "HLM, participants three data points used. , participants least three data points (.e., 4 ) used. package now offers combined approaches: classic combination statistical distribution-based approaches also combination statistical anchor-based approaches

title: clinicalsignificance (development version)
